title: Davidson Joins OTI, New America Reforms in Obama Budget, and More
html:
MEDIA

  • President Obama's fiscal year 2015 budget includes a number of reforms Jason Delisle and New America's Education Policy Program recommended, including a new loan forgiveness threshold for borrowers with high levels of debt, and a cap on Public Sector Loan Forgiveness
  • Jason Delisle & Clare McCann's federal education budget commentary took off, receiving multiple mentions throughout the press. Clare had a piece in The Atlantic, the Christian Science Monitor cited her in a piece on Obama and the FAFSA, and the Baltimore Sun gave her a nod as well. Reid Cramer's op-ed on The War on Poverty ran in The Hill
  • College Blackout has mentions in the National Review Online, Reuters and the Wall Street Journal
  • The announcement of Alan Davidson as Vice President for Technology Policy and Strategy, and Director of the Open Technology Institute and of Sascha Meinrath as the Director of our new X-Lab program received coverage in The Hill and POLITICO Morning Tech
  • Brigid Schulte has mentions in TIME and Forbes, and her articles appeared in The Washington Post and NPR
  • Chris Leonard got shout-out in Nicholas Kristof's column in the New York Times as well as in Salon

title: Drutman Publishes Book on Lobbying, New America Holds Second Event on Race in America, and More
html:
POLICY

  • On March 18, OTI Senior Policy Counsel Laura Moy testified before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing, and Trade on the consumer privacy issues related to the new data breach bill. Here's her written testimony.
  • Peter W. Singer spoke to Marines at the US Marine Base Quantico about cybersecurity.

BOOKS

  • Lee Drutman’s book, The Business of America is Lobbying, was published this week. He’ll be discussing more about the book with NPR’s Peter Overby at an event on April 16h at New America. Register here!

EVENTS

  • New America hosted the second event in the "From Moment to Movement" Series: Conversations on Race in America in collaboration with Howard University, exploring the topic “Broken Windows or Broken Badges? Can Reform Improve Policing?” Kirsten Holtz helped organize the event, which was moderated by Laurenellen McCann. Participants included Sgt. Delroy A. Burton (Chairman, DC Police Union), Dr. Greg Carr (Associate Professor & Chair, The Department of Afro-American Studies, Howard University), Tanya Clay House (Director of Public Policy, Lawyers’ Committee for Civil Rights Under Law), and Alex Altman (TIME).
  • Suzanne DiMaggio spoke at J Street's national conference on a panel focused on the nuclear negotiations with Iran with Amb. Tom Pickering and Brig. General Shlomo Brom.

BEST OF THE BLOGS

  • South Asia Channel: Ali Karimi wrote an excellent article about how Afghanistan must catch-up in urbanization, so that it does not continue to fall behind, and Michael Kugelman wrote a piece about Afghan President Ashraf Ghani’s upcoming trip to Washington DC.

MAJOR MEDIA

  • Peter W. Singer launched the first episode of “The Cybersecurity Podcast,” a new venture between New America and “Passcode,” the Christian Science Monitor ‘s cybersecurity section. Peter will host the podcast along with Sara Sorcher, editor of “Passcode.” Read more about it in FP’s The Best Defense, and tune in to the new podcast here! Peter was also spoke on two panels at SXSW, and was quoted in a Washington Post article about Pakistan deploying drones against terrorists.
  • Opportunity@Work and co-founder Byron Auguste were featured in a Fortune Mag piece about the future of job search, which will focus on closing the information gap between companies and people looking for work.  
  • The recent ISP hosted event with General Michael Hayden received a write-up in The Guardian.
  • Peter Bergen and David Sterman published an article on CNN.com about the attack in Tunisia, and ISP’s work on right wing extremism was cited in an article by The Atlantic.
  • Douglas Ollivant was interviewed on the PBS Newshour about the battle for Tikrit.
  • Rebecca MacKinnon was interviewed on Marketplace this week, about the cost of keeping social media sites in check.
  • NYT columnist Joe Nocera devoted his March 10th column to Kevin Carey’s new book, End of College. Kevin’s new book was also mentioned in the Washington Post, Portland Press Herald, Times Union, and the Christian Science Monitor.
  • EdCentral's latest policy paper "Why Student Loans Are Different" by Jason Delisle and Alexander Holt was mentioned in Pacific Standard.
  • Conor Williams wrote an op-ed for Talking Points Memo.
  • Shane Harris was on the Diane Rehm Show’s Friday News Roundup.
